At that time, the six non-Buddhist teachers gave rise to jealousy and all came to King Prasenajit, saying:
'Great King, you should know:
Your kingdom is pure, peaceful, and quiet, truly a place for renunciant monks to dwell.
Therefore, we have come here for this matter.
The Great King governs with the right Dharma and removes troubles for the people.

In this country, there are elders who have been here for a long time, yet he relies on the royal lineage and does not give rise to respect.
If he is of the royal lineage, he should govern the people; if he has gone forth, he should respect the elders.
Great King, listen well:
The Å›ramaá¹‡a Gautama truly was not born into the royal lineage.
If the ÅšÄkya monk has parents, how can he rob others of their parents?
Great King!
In my scriptures it is said:
After a thousand years, a strange, illusory, and deceptive thing will appear.
It is called the Åšramaá¹‡a Gautama.
Therefore you should know:
The Åšramaá¹‡a Gautama has no father and no mother.
If he has parents, how can he say that all dharmas are impermanent, suffering, empty, without self, without action, and without experience?
By means of magical arts, he deceives sentient beings. The foolish believe and accept it, while the wise abandon it.
Great King!

The ruler and king are the parents of the world. He rules like a scale, like the earth, like the wind, like fire, like a road, like a river, like a bridge, like a lamp, like the sun, like the moon. He rules according to the Dharma, without discriminating between enemies and friends.
The Åšramaá¹‡a Gautama does not allow me to live. Wherever I go, he chases after me and does not let me go.

if I defeat him, he will submit to me.'
The king said:
'Venerable ones!

' The six teachers replied:

The Å›ramaá¹‡a Gautama uses his magical arts to deceive and ensnare all people and brÄhmans, leaving none unconquered.

The king said:

'Great King!

The king said:

At that time, King Prasenajit immediately ordered his carriage to be prepared and came to where I was. He bowed his head in respect, circumambulated me three times to the right, and then sat to one side. He said to me:

The Buddha said:

Excellent, excellent!
But you should build more monasteries in various places in this country.

If I compete with them in their spiritual powers, many in their assembly will accept the teachings. This place is too small, how can it accommodate them?'
Good man!
At that time, for the sake of the six masters, I manifested great and rare spiritual transformations for fifteen days, starting from the first day.
At that time, innumerable beings gave rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment;
incalculable beings gave rise to faith and no longer doubted the Three Jewels;
the innumerable disciples of the six masters destroyed their views of false teachings and went forth in the true Dharma;
incalculable beings attained the irreversible mind of enlightenment;
incalculable beings attained dhÄraá¹‡Ä«s and various samÄdhi gates;

At that time, MaudgalyÄyana silently assented. In the time it takes for a strong man to flex his arm, he went to the heavens and arrived before the World-Honored One. He said to the Buddha:
'The four assemblies in JambudvÄ«pa are thirsting for the TathÄgata and long to see and hear the Dharma.

'You should quickly return to JambudvÄ«pa and tell the kings of the various countries and the fourfold assembly:

After seven days had passed, the Buddha, together with Åšakra, BrahmÄ, MÄra, countless celestial sons, and all the gods and humans of the ÅšuddhÄvÄsa Heaven, surrounded him in front and behind as he arrived at the city of Vá¹›ji. The Great Lion's Roar made this statement:
Only in my Dharma are there Å›ramaá¹‡as and brÄhmaá¹‡as. All dharmas are impermanent, without self, nirvÄá¹‡a is tranquil, and free from all faults.

Good man!
Once, I was staying in the mango grove of VaiÅ›ÄlÄ«.
At that time, the mango girl knew that I was there and wanted to come to me.
At that time, I told the bhiká¹£us, You should contemplate the foundations of mindfulness, skillfully cultivate wisdom, and in your practice, do not be negligent.
What is meant by contemplating the foundations of mindfulness?

If there is a bhiká¹£u who observes the internal body but does not see a self or what belongs to a self, observes the external body and the internal and external body but does not see a self or what belongs to a self, and observes feelings, mind, and dharmas in the same way, this is called the foundations of mindfulness.

At that time, the woman Amra came to where I was, bowed her head to my feet, circumambulated me three times to the right, and after completing her respectful salutations, sat to one side.

At that time, I expounded the Dharma for the woman Amra in accordance with her capacity.
After she heard it, she gave rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment.

At that time, there were five hundred Licchavi youths in that city who came to where I was, bowed their heads to my feet, circumambulated me three times to the right, completed their respectful salutations, and sat to one side.
I then again expounded the Dharma for the Licchavi youths in accordance with their capacities:
'Good men!
The five fruits of indulgence are as follows.
What are the five?

First, one does not obtain mastery over wealth and profit; second, one's bad reputation spreads everywhere; third, one does not enjoy giving to the poor; fourth, one does not enjoy seeing the four assemblies; fifth, one does not obtain the body of the gods.
Good men,
Because of not being negligent, one can give rise to worldly and supramundane dharmas.
If there are those who wish to attain supreme, perfect enlightenment, they should diligently cultivate the dharma of not being negligent.
As for being negligent, one obtains thirteen fruits and retributions.
What are the thirteen?

First, delighting in worldly work; second, delighting in speaking of useless words; third, always delighting in sleeping for a long time; fourth, delighting in speaking of worldly matters; fifth, always delighting in befriending evil companions; sixth, being lazy and indolent; seventh, always being despised by others; eighth, even if one hears something, one quickly forgets it; ninth, delighting in dwelling in border regions; tenth, being unable to subdue the senses; eleventh, not knowing contentment in eating; twelfth, not delighting in emptiness and tranquility; thirteenth, having an incorrect view. These are called the thirteen.
Good men!
Those who are negligent, even if they get close to the Buddha and the Buddha's disciples, are still far away.
The Licchavi youths said:
'We ourselves know that we are negligent people.
Why is it so?
If we were not negligent, the TathÄgata, the Dharma King, would appear in our country.'
At that time, in the great assembly, there was a brÄhman youth named Ajita who said to the Licchavi people:
'Excellent, excellent!
As you have said, King BimbisÄra has already gained great benefits.
The TathÄgata, the World-Honored One, has appeared in his country, just like a beautiful lotus flower born in a great pond. Although it is born in the water, the water cannot defile it.
Licchavi youths!
The Buddha is also like this. Although he was born in that country, he is not hindered by worldly dharmas.
The Buddhas, the World-Honored Ones, have no coming out and no entering. For the sake of sentient beings, they appear in the world and are not hindered by worldly dharmas.

You yourselves are deluded, indulging in the five desires, not knowing to approach and go to the TathÄgata. Therefore, you are called negligent people, not that the Buddha's appearance in the country of Magadha is called negligence.
Why is it so?
The TathÄgata, the World-Honored One, is like the sun and moon, not appearing in the world for one or two people.
' At that time, the Licchavis, having heard these words, immediately gave rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment.
They further said:
'Excellent, excellent!
Son of Unconquerable!
You have eloquently spoken such excellent and wonderful words.'
At that time, the Licchavis each took off one of their garments and offered it to Unconquerable.
Unconquerable received them and presented them to me, further saying:
'World-Honored One!
I have obtained these garments from the Licchavis. I only pray that the TathÄgata, out of compassion for sentient beings, will accept my offerings.
I felt pity for their lack of victory and accepted them.
At that time, the Licchavis all joined their palms and said:
We only wish that the TathÄgata would temporarily reside in this land for one summer retreat and accept our humble offerings.
I then silently accepted the Licchavis' invitation.
At that time, the six non-Buddhist teachers heard of this and, following each other, went to VÄrÄá¹‡asÄ«.
At that time, I went to VÄrÄá¹‡asÄ« and stayed by the side of the Varaá¹‡Ä River.
At that time, there was an elder's son in VÄrÄá¹‡asÄ« named Ratnaskandha who was addicted to the five desires and did not know impermanence.

Because I had arrived, he naturally attained the contemplation of white bones. He saw that his palace, concubines, and maidservants were all white bones, and he became frightened, as if by a knife, poison, a thief, or fire.
He left his house and came to where I was. Along the way, he said:
Gautama Åšramaá¹‡a!
I am now like someone being chased by thieves, I am very frightened, please save me.'
The Buddha said:
'Good man!
The Buddha, the Dharma, and the Saá¹…gha are at peace and have nothing to fear.'
The elder's son said:
'If there is nothing to fear in the Three Jewels, then I too should attain fearlessness.'
I then allowed him to leave home and practice the Way.
At that time, the elder's son had fifty friends who had heard from afar that Baocheng had left home in disgust, so they all agreed and left home together.
The six masters heard this and went on to the great city of Campa.

At that time, all the people of the country of Campa revered the followers of the six masters, and had never heard of the names of the Buddha, Dharma, and Saá¹…gha. There were many people who committed extremely evil deeds.
At that time, for the sake of sentient beings, I went to the city of Campa.
At that time, there was a great elder in the city who had no heir. He served the six masters in order to seek a son.
Not long after, his wife became pregnant.
The elder, knowing this, went to the six masters with joy and said:
My wife is pregnant. Is it a boy or a girl?
The six masters replied:
If it is born, it will definitely be a girl.
Hearing this, the elder became sorrowful.
Again, a friend came and said to the elder:
Why are you so sorrowful?
The elder replied:
My wife is pregnant, and I do not know whether it is a boy or a girl, so I asked the six masters.
The six masters said:
According to our method of divination, if it is born, it will definitely be a girl.
Hearing this, I think to myself that I am old and have immeasurable wealth. If it is not a boy, there is no one to whom I can entrust it. This is why I am sorrowful.
The friend said again:
You lack wisdom.
Have you not heard this before?
Who were the disciples of the brothers UruvilvÄ-KÄÅ›yapa and so on?
Were they disciples of the Buddha?

If the six non-Buddhist teachers were omniscient, why did KÄÅ›yapa abandon them and become a disciple of the Buddha?

Moreover, ÅšÄriputra, MaudgalyÄyana and so on, and the various kings such as BimbisÄra, the various kings' wives such as Queen MallikÄ, and the various country elders such as Sudatta, are these not disciples of the Buddha?
The wild ghosts, King AjÄtaÅ›atru, the drunken elephant that protected wealth, Aá¹…gulimÄla with his rampant evil mind who wanted to kill his mother, were these not tamed by the TathÄgata?

The TathÄgata, the World-Honored One, knows and sees all dharmas without obstruction, and is therefore called the Buddha;

The World-Honored One's words are never contradictory, but the six masters are not so. How can they be trusted?
The TathÄgata is now staying nearby. If you want to truly know, you should go to the Buddha.
' At that time, the elder then came to where I was with that person, bowed his head to my feet, circumambulated me three times to the right, joined his palms, knelt for a long time, and said:
'The World-Honored One is equal and non-dual towards all sentient beings, with the same appearance towards enemies and friends;
I am bound by the bonds of love and am unable to be without duality towards enemies and friends.
I now want to ask the TathÄgata about worldly matters, but I am deeply ashamed and afraid, and dare not speak.
World-Honored One!
My wife is pregnant, and the six masters have said:
'If she gives birth, it will definitely be a girl.'

' The Buddha said:
'Elder!
There is no doubt that your wife is pregnant with a boy.
After the child is born, his blessings and virtues will be incomparable.
At that time, the elder, having heard these words, gave rise to great joy and then withdrew back home.
At that time, the six masters heard my profound prediction:
'The one who is born will be a boy with great blessings and virtues.'
Their minds became jealous, and they mixed poison with Ämalaka fruit, brought it to the elder's house and said to him:
'How wonderful! Gautama skillfully explained the signs.
Your wife is about to give birth, you should take this medicine.
After taking this medicine, the child will be upright and the delivery will be without trouble.'
The elder joyfully accepted the poisonous medicine and gave it to his wife to take. After taking it, she died immediately.
The six masters rejoiced and went around the city, shouting loudly, saying:
'The Å›ramaá¹‡a Gautama predicted that the wife of that elder will give birth to a boy, whose blessings and virtues will be unsurpassed in the world.
Now, before the child is born, the mother has already lost her life.'
At that time, the elder again gave rise to faith in me. He then followed worldly customs to embalm and coffin the body, sent it outside the city, piled up dry firewood, and cremated it with fire.
I clearly saw this matter with the eyes of the Way. I instructed Ä€nanda:
Take my robe and come with me. I wish to go there and destroy the wrong views.
At that time, VaiÅ›ravaá¹‡a King told the great general Maá¹‡ibhadra:

At that time, the six masters saw me coming from afar and each said to each other:
The Åšramaá¹‡a Gautama came to this charnel ground to eat meat?
At that time, there were many upÄsakas who had not yet attained the Dharma eye. Each felt ashamed and afraid and said to me:
That wife has already died. Please do not go.
At that time, Ä€nanda said to the people:
Wait a moment. The TathÄgata will soon extensively reveal the realm of all buddhas.
When I arrived, I sat on the lion seat.
The elder said:
What you say is not contradictory, so you can be called the World-Honored One.
Since the mother has already passed away, how can you give birth to a child?
I said:
Elder!
At that time, you did not ask at all about the mother's life span, but only asked whether the child in the womb was a boy or a girl.
The buddhas, the tathÄgatas, speak without contradiction. Therefore, you should know that you will definitely have a child.
At that time, the dead body was burned by fire and the belly split open. The child emerged from within, sitting upright in the fire, like a mandarin duck on a lotus flower platform.
When the six masters saw this, they said again:
How strange, Gautama!
You are good at performing illusions.
When the elder saw this, he was delighted and scolded the six masters:
'If you say it's an illusion, why don't you create one yourself?'
At that time, I told JÄ«vaka:
'Go into the fire and carry the child out.'
When JÄ«vaka was about to go, the six masters pulled him forward and said to JÄ«vaka:
'The illusory magic created by the Åšramaá¹‡a Gautama may or may not always work.
If it doesn't work, it may burn and harm you. Why do you believe his words?'
JÄ«vaka replied:
'Even if the TathÄgata told me to enter AvÄ«ci Hell, the raging flames there would not be able to burn me, let alone the fires of the world.'
At that time, JÄ«vaka entered the mass of fireâ€”just like entering the cool waters of a great riverâ€”and held the child. He returned to where I was and handed the child to me.
After I received the child, I told the elder:
'The lifespan of all beings is uncertain, like bubbles on water.
If sentient beings have heavy karmic consequences, fire cannot burn them and poison cannot harm them.
This child's karmic retribution is not something I created.
At that time, the elder said:
Excellent, World-Honored One!
If this child can exhaust his heavenly life, I only wish that the TathÄgata would give him a name.
The Buddha said:
Elder!
Since this child was born in a raging fire, the fire is called TÄ«rtha, so he should be named TÄ«rtha.
At that time, the immeasurable sentient beings in the assembly who witnessed my spiritual transformation gave rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment.
At that time, the six masters wandered through six cities but could not stay in any of them. Ashamed and with heads lowered, they returned to this city of KuÅ›inagara.
Having arrived here, they proclaimed:
'People should know that:
Åšramaá¹‡a Gautama is a great magician who deceives the world and has been to the six great cities.
It is like a magician conjuring up four armies, namely, chariot troops, cavalry, elephant troops, and infantry.
He also conjures up various ornaments, cities, palaces, ponds, and trees.

The Å›ramaá¹‡a Gautama is also like this. He conjures up the form of a king in order to expound the Dharma. He may take on the form of a Å›ramaá¹‡a, a brÄhmaá¹‡a, a male, a female, a small body, a large body, or the form of an animal, ghost, or spirit. He may sometimes speak of impermanence or sometimes speak of permanence, sometimes speak of suffering or sometimes speak of happiness, sometimes speak of self or sometimes speak of non-self, sometimes speak of purity or sometimes speak of impurity, sometimes speak of existence or sometimes speak of non-existence. What he does is false, and therefore it is called an illusion.
It is like planting a seed and obtaining a fruit according to the seed.
The Å›ramaá¹‡a Gautama is also like this. Born from MÄyÄ, since the mother is an illusion, can the son not be so?
The Å›ramaá¹‡a Gautama has no true knowledge and insight.
The brÄhmaá¹‡as, even though they practice austerities for years and uphold precepts, still say they do not have true knowledge and insight.
How much less so for Gautama, who is young, shallow in learning, does not practice austerities, and yet claims to have true knowledge and insight?
If one can practice austerities for seven years and still see little, how much less so for one who practices for less than six years?
Foolish people without wisdom believe and accept his teachings.
Just as a great magician deceives the foolish, so too is the Å›ramaá¹‡a Gautama.
Good man!
In this way, these six teachers greatly increase the wrong views of beings in this city.
Good man!

I, seeing this, give rise to compassion. With my spiritual powers, I invite the great bodhisattvas from the ten directions to gather in this forest, filling it everywhere for forty yojanas. Now, I will roar the great lion's roar within this assembly.
Good man!
Although there are many teachings in empty places, it cannot be called the lion's roar. Only in this assembly of wise people can it truly be called the great lion's roar.
The lion's roar means teaching that all phenomena are impermanent, suffering, without self, and impure, while only teaching that the TathÄgata is permanent, blissful, self, and pure.
At that time, the six teachers said again:
If Gautama has a self, I also have a self.
What we call a self is called a self because it sees.
Gautama!
It is like a person who sees objects in the direction they face. I am also like this. The direction is analogous to the eyes, and seeing is analogous to the self.
The Buddha told the six teachers:
If you say that what sees is called a self, this is not so.
Why is it so?
The analogy you gave of seeing in a direction is that when a person faces one direction, all six sense faculties are used.
If there definitely is a self that sees through the eyes, why can't it perceive all objects through a single faculty?
If a single faculty cannot simultaneously perceive the six sense objects, one should know there is no self.
The analogy you cited, although it has passed a hundred years, the seer is the cause of what is seen, and what is seen is no different.
If the eye faculty is like this, even if one grows old and the faculties mature, it should still be no different.
Because the person changes, one sees inside and outside.
If the eye faculty is like this, it should also see inside and outside simultaneously.
If it does not see, how can there be a self?'
The six teachers said again:
'Gautama!
If there is no self, who can see?'
The Buddha said:
'There is form, there is light, there is mind, there is eye, these four combine and are called seeing, in this there is truly no seer or receiver.
Sentient beings are upside down, saying there is a seer and a receiver.
For this reason, all sentient beings see what is upside down, while the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas see what is true.
If the six masters say that form is the self, this is also unreasonable.
Why is it so?
Form is not really the self.
If form were the self, one should not be able to obtain an ugly appearance.
Why are there also distinctions in the four castes?
Why are they not all of one kind, the brahmins?
Why are they subject to others, not having self-mastery, with deficient faculties, born incomplete?
Why do they not take on the bodies of the gods, but experience the various bodies of hell-dwellers, animals, and hungry ghosts?
If one cannot do as one wishes, one should know that there is definitely no self.
Because there is no self, it is called impermanent;
because it is impermanent, it is suffering;
because it is suffering, it is empty;
because it is empty, it is upside down;
because it is upside down, all sentient beings revolve in birth and death.
feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness are also like this.
Six teachers!
The TathÄgata, the World-Honored One, has permanently severed the bonds of form up to the bonds of consciousness, and therefore is called permanent, blissful, self, and pure.
Furthermore, form is precisely the causes and conditions.
If it is the causes and conditions, then it is called non-self;
if it is non-self, then it is called suffering and empty.
The TathÄgata's body is not the causes and conditions;
because it is not the causes and conditions, it is called having a self;
if it has a self, then it is permanent, blissful, and pure.'
The six teachers said again:
'Gautama!
Form is also not the self, up to consciousness is also not the self.
The self is omnipresent, just like empty space.'
The Buddha said:
'If it is omnipresent, then it should not be said that you have never seen it before;
if you have never seen it before, then it is known that this seeing originally did not exist but now exists;
if it originally did not exist but now exists, then it is called impermanent;
If it is impermanent, how can you say it is all-pervading?
If it exists everywhere, then bodies should exist in all five realms;
if there are bodies, then each should experience retribution;
if each experiences retribution, how can you say it transmigrates through the human and heavenly realms?
You say it is all-pervading, is it one or many?
If the self is one, then there would be no father, son, enemy, friend, or neutral person;
if the self is many, then the five faculties of all sentient beings should be equal.

All karmic actions and wisdom should also be like this. If so, how can you say there are those with complete and incomplete faculties, and distinctions between good and evil actions, and between the foolish and the wise?'
'Gautama!
The self of sentient beings has no boundaries.
Dharma and non-Dharma have their limits. Sentient beings who cultivate the Dharma attain good bodies, while those who practice non-Dharma attain evil bodies.
For this reason, the karmic fruits of sentient beings cannot be without distinctions.
The Buddha said:
Six masters!
If dharmas and non-dharmas are like this, then I am not all-pervading.
If I were all-pervading, then I should reach everywhere.
If I reached everywhere, then a person who cultivates goodness should also have evil, and a person who practices evil should also have goodness.
If it is not so, how can you say I am all-pervading?
Gautama!
It is like a room with a hundred thousand lamps, each with its own light, not obstructing each other.
The self of sentient beings is also like this, cultivating goodness and practicing evil, not mixed together.
If you say the self is like a lamp, that is not so.
Why is it so?
The light of that lamp arises from conditions.
Because the lamp increases, the light also increases;
The self of sentient beings is not like this.
The light comes out of the lamp and stays in a different place;
The self of sentient beings cannot be like this, coming out of the body and residing in a different place.
